utterances: I do think there's a third issue, and that is largely called the green issue or the environmental issue.

Democrats I think have identified that thinking about environmental justice, linking this up with our presence in the Middle East, and somehow really kind of framing the ways that this most recent Congress, 109th, under the guise of apparently making environmental policy, actually turned back the clock, turned back funding on a variety of questions of clean air and clean water to the extent that the Democrats have found green to be the new issue for them.
They are going to push Republicans to have to get onboard with passing some legislation around it.

We're reporting next on the side effects of our mass media.
Every year, we get a little bit closer to a world where you get what you want when you want it - at least when it comes to entertainment.
New technologies have given us access to countless channels for music and television and film.
But NPR's Laura Sydell wonders whether convenience is costing us a sense of common culture.
(Soundbite of ""Seinfeld"" theme music)
Remember the ""Seinfeld"" episode when a reporter mistakenly thought that Jerry and George were lovers?
(Soundbite of TV show ""Seinfeld"")
We did the whole thing for your benefit.
We knew you were eavesdropping.
That's why my friend said all that.
It was on purpose.
We're not gay - not that there's anything wrong with that.
And not that there's anything wrong with it if you didn't see the episode or any of the other famous ones - you know, yadda, yadda, yadda.
Even if you didn't see them, you knew about them.
That's Clifford Nass, Stanford University communications professor.
He says ""Seinfeld,"" a show about nothing, actually meant something.
Americans laughed together.
That's really what marks cultural touchstones, things that people are aware of, that they can share, that they can make reference to that they don't actually have to consume themselves.
More than 40 percent of American households saw the final episode of ""Seinfeld"" in the spring of 1998, according to the Nielsen Company.
Fast-forward about 11 years.

American Idol"" may be the most popular program on television today, but only about 16 percent of American households saw this year's finale.

There's Lifetime for women, Spike for men, the Syfy channel.
Add on to that the Internet and YouTube.
Professor Abigail De Kosnik with U.C.
Berkeley's Center for New Media says once the nation shared trusted anchors like Walter Cronkite and Peter Jennings.
Now everyone can find the news that suits their taste.
Fox News will take a stance that represents a certain set of values, and ""The Daily Show"" will take a stance that has a very different ideology than Fox News.

For better or for worse, when we did have 60 million people watching any one network's nightly new program, that meant that 60 million people had to all receive the same information and make up their minds about it and be in dialogue with one another about it.
De Kosnik says people watch the news they find agreeable, and then they use the Internet to chat with the people who share their tastes and opinions.
Stanford Professor Clifford Nass says social scientists find the current trends worrisome.
There have never been cultures or societies in which there weren't a very large set of shared ideas, norms, values, stories, cultures, etc. We've just never seen that before.
Of course, having a mainstream culture also meant that some people felt left out.
